Kung Pao Chicken Skewers

Jump to Recipe

Get ready to spice up your grilling game with these mouthwatering Kung Pao Chicken Skewers! Perfect for summer barbecues or a quick weeknight dinner, this recipe combines the classic flavors of the beloved Kung Pao dish with the convenience of skewers. Tender chicken breast pieces are marinated in a savory blend of soy sauce, peanut butter, and honey, infused with aromatic garlic and ginger, and kicked up a notch with a hint of heat from red pepper flakes. Not only are these skewers incredibly delicious, but they also make for an eye-catching presentation at your next gathering. Served with a sprinkle of chopped peanuts and fresh scallions, these Kung Pao Chicken Skewers are bound to become a family favorite. Plus, they’re easy to prepare and grill to perfection, making them a hassle-free option for any occasion. Whether you're a grilling novice or a seasoned pro, follow this step-by-step recipe to create a dish that’s sure to impress your friends and family!

Ingredients

chicken breast

Choose fresh, boneless, and skinless chicken breasts for the best flavor and texture. If you're looking for a leaner option, turkey breast can also be used as a substitute. For added moisture and flavor, consider marinating the chicken for longer than 10 minutes, up to 2 hours.

soy sauce

Use low-sodium soy sauce to control sodium levels in your dish. If you need a gluten-free option, tamari is a great substitute. For a deeper flavor, consider using dark soy sauce, but use it sparingly as it has a stronger taste.

peanut butter

Opt for natural peanut butter without added sugars or oils for a healthier choice. If you have a nut allergy, sunflower seed butter or tahini can serve as excellent substitutes. To enhance the peanut flavor, try toasting the peanut butter in a pan briefly before mixing it into the marinade.

honey

If you prefer a vegan option, maple syrup or agave nectar can replace honey. For a more robust flavor, consider using brown sugar or coconut sugar. Make sure to adjust the quantity based on the sweetness level you desire.

rice vinegar

Rice vinegar adds a mild, slightly sweet flavor. If you don't have it on hand, apple cider vinegar or white wine vinegar can be good substitutes. To enhance the flavor, try using seasoned rice vinegar, which has added sugar and salt.

garlic, minced

Fresh garlic yields the best flavor, but if you're short on time, garlic powder can be used as a substitute (1/8 tsp per clove). To mellow the garlic flavor, you can roast the cloves before mincing them.

ginger, minced

Fresh ginger is preferred for its aromatic qualities. If you don't have fresh ginger, ground ginger can be used (1/4 tsp per teaspoon of fresh ginger). Grating the ginger can release more flavor than mincing.

red pepper flakes

Adjust the amount based on your heat tolerance; you can also use fresh chopped chili peppers for a different heat profile. If you want a milder version, consider using sweet paprika instead.

wooden skewers

Soak the skewers in water for at least 10 minutes to prevent them from burning on the grill. If you prefer, metal skewers can be used as they don't require soaking and can be reused.

chopped peanuts

Roast the peanuts lightly in a dry pan to enhance their flavor before adding them as a garnish. If you're allergic to peanuts, you can use chopped cashews or almonds instead.

scallions, sliced

Use both the white and green parts of the scallions for added color and flavor. If you don't have scallions, finely chopped chives or shallots can be a suitable alternative.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Prepare the Chicken

    Begin by cutting the chicken breast into bite-sized pieces, approximately 1 to 2 inches in size. This ensures even cooking and makes the skewers easy to eat. Set the chicken aside.

  • Step 2: Make the Marinade

    In a medium-sized bowl, combine 1/4 cup soy sauce, 2 tablespoons peanut butter, 1 tablespoon honey, 1 tablespoon rice vinegar, 2 minced garlic cloves, 1 teaspoon minced ginger, and 1 teaspoon red pepper flakes. Whisk together until smooth, creating a delicious marinade.

  • Step 3: Marinate the Chicken

    Add the chicken pieces to the marinade, stirring well to ensure each piece is coated. For best results, let the chicken marinate for at least 10 minutes; however, if you have more time, marinating for 30 minutes to an hour will enhance the flavors significantly.

  • Step 4: Prepare the Skewers

    While the chicken is marinating, soak 8 wooden skewers in water for about 10 minutes. Soaking prevents the skewers from burning on the grill.

  • Step 5: Preheat the Grill

    Preheat your grill to medium-high heat (around 375°F to 400°F). This temperature is ideal for grilling chicken, allowing it to cook through without burning.

  • Step 6: Assemble the Skewers

    Once the chicken has marinated, thread the pieces onto the soaked skewers. Aim for 4 to 5 pieces of chicken per skewer, leaving a little space between each piece for even cooking.

  • Step 7: Grill the Skewers

    Place the skewers on the preheated grill. Grill for about 10 minutes, turning occasionally to ensure they cook evenly and develop a nice char. The chicken is done when it reaches an internal temperature of 165°F.

  • Step 8: Serve and Garnish

    Remove the skewers from the grill and place them on a serving platter. Sprinkle with 1/4 cup chopped peanuts and the sliced scallions just before serving for added crunch and flavor.

Frequently Asked Questions

How do I properly cut chicken breast into bite-sized pieces?

Place the chicken breast on a cutting board and use a sharp knife to slice it into even pieces, about 1 to 1.5 inches in size. This helps them cook evenly. Always cut against the grain for tenderness.

What can I substitute for soy sauce if I don't have it?

You can use tamari (a gluten-free alternative) or coconut aminos as a substitute for soy sauce. They both provide a similar savory flavor.

How can I make the marinade stick better to the chicken?

Make sure to coat the chicken pieces well by tossing them in the marinade. Letting them marinate longer than 10 minutes (up to a few hours) in the fridge will also enhance the flavor.

Why should I soak the wooden skewers before grilling?

Soaking wooden skewers in water for at least 10 minutes prevents them from burning on the grill, which helps keep your food intact.

How do I know when the chicken is fully cooked?

Chicken is fully cooked when it reaches an internal temperature of 165°F (75°C). You can use a meat thermometer to check, or cut into a piece to ensure there is no pink in the center.

What if I don't have a grill? Can I cook these skewers in the oven?

Yes! You can bake the skewers in the oven at 400°F (200°C) for about 15-20 minutes, turning halfway through. You can also broil them for a few minutes to get a charred effect.

How should I store leftover skewers?

Store any leftover skewers in an airtight container in the refrigerator for up to 3 days. Reheat gently in the microwave or in the oven.

What can I serve with Kung Pao Chicken Skewers?

These skewers pair well with steamed rice, fried rice, or a fresh salad. You can also serve them with extra peanut sauce for dipping.

How spicy are these skewers?

The red pepper flakes add heat, but you can adjust the amount to your taste. Start with half the amount if you're sensitive to spice.

Can I add vegetables to the skewers?

Absolutely! Bell peppers, zucchini, and onions make great additions. Just cut them into similar-sized pieces as the chicken for even cooking.

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

To accommodate gluten-sensitive diners, use gluten-free soy sauce or tamari in the marinade. For a vegetarian alternative, substitute chicken with cubed firm tofu or tempeh, marinating and grilling them similarly. If nut allergies are a concern, replace peanut butter with sunflower seed butter and skip the chopped peanuts, or use seeds as a garnish.

Pairings

Serve Kung Pao Chicken Skewers with a side of fragrant jasmine rice or quinoa to soak up the flavorful marinade. For a refreshing contrast, add a cucumber salad dressed with sesame oil and rice vinegar. For beverages, consider pairing with a crisp, cold lager, a fruity white wine like Sauvignon Blanc, or a non-alcoholic option like iced green tea with lemon to balance the dish's spiciness.

Serving Suggestions

Present the skewers on a large platter, garnished with additional chopped peanuts and scallions for a pop of color. Offer small bowls of extra peanut sauce for dipping alongside the skewers. For a more communal dining experience, consider serving them with warm tortillas or lettuce leaves, allowing guests to make their own wraps with the chicken and any desired accompaniments such as fresh herbs or sliced vegetables.

Kung Pao Chicken Skewers

25 min
$12.5
350 kcal
Difficulty: 30%
Servings: 4

Allergens:

Peanuts

Dietary Tags:

Gluten-FreeNut-Free

Cuisine:

Chinese

Course:

Main CourseAppetizer

Tags:

GrillingQuick MealAsian-Inspired

Description

Succulent chicken skewers marinated in a spicy Kung Pao sauce, grilled to perfection and garnished with peanuts and scallions.

Ingredients

  • chicken breast: 1 lb
  • soy sauce: 1/4 cup
  • peanut butter: 2 tbsp
  • honey: 1 tbsp
  • rice vinegar: 1 tbsp
  • garlic, minced: 2 cloves
  • ginger, minced: 1 tsp
  • red pepper flakes: 1 tsp
  • wooden skewers: 8
  • chopped peanuts: 1/4 cup
  • scallions, sliced: 2

Date Created:

11/17/2024
